questions.question: What is a file?
options: A collection of logically related records
questions.explanation: A file is a collection of logically related records. It is used to store data on hard disk or other storage devices.

questions.question: How many types of data communication does a program usually require?
questions.explanation: A program usually requires two types of data communication: (i) writing data on datafile, (ii) reading data from datafile.

questions.question: The data flow from keyboard to memory and from memory to storage device is called:
questions.explanation: The data flow from keyboard → memory → hard disk/storage device is called output stream where stream is the flow of data.

questions.question: Which header file is required for output stream?
questions.explanation: Output stream requires an ofstream.h header file.

questions.question: The data flow from storage device to memory and from memory to output device is called:
questions.explanation: The data flow from datafile → memory → output device (screen) is called input stream.

questions.question: Which header file is required for input stream?
questions.explanation: Input stream requires ifstream.h header file.

questions.question: If both input stream and output stream are used in the same program, which header file is required?
questions.explanation: If both input stream and output stream are used in the same program then header file fstream.h is required.

questions.question: If fstream.h is included in the program, do you need to include iostream.h explicitly?
questions.explanation: If header file fstream.h is included in the program, there is no need to include iostream.h explicitly.

questions.question: What must be done before reading data from or writing data to a datafile?
questions.explanation: File has to be opened, before reading data from datafile or writing data on the datafile.

questions.question: How many ways can a file be opened?
questions.explanation: A file can be opened in two ways: (i) using constructor function of a class, (ii) using the member function open() of the class.

questions.question: Which statement opens a file in output mode using constructor?
questions.explanation: The statement ofstream outfile("STU.DAT"); opens the file STU.DAT in output mode, i.e., for writing data on the file.

questions.question: Which statement opens a file in input mode using constructor?
questions.explanation: The statement ifstream infile("STU.DAT"); opens the file "STU.DAT" in input mode, i.e., for reading purpose.

questions.question: What is ofstream?
options: A class available in the compiler file
questions.explanation: ofstream is a class available in the compiler file. outfile is any user defined object of this class.

questions.question: Which operator is used for writing data to a file?
questions.explanation: The statements outfile << "TOTAL MARKS" << "\n"; and outfile << total << "\n"; are used for writing data on the file.

questions.question: Which operator is used for reading data from a file?
questions.explanation: The statements infile >> string; and infile >> number; read the data from the data file.

questions.question: What is the purpose of newline character when writing to files?
options: To move the pointer to the next line
questions.explanation: The newline character is used for moving the pointer to the next line when writing data to files.

questions.question: The function open() can be used to:
options: Open multiple files that use the same stream object
questions.explanation: The function open() can be used to open multiple files that use the same stream object.

questions.question: What is the general format of open() function with access mode?
questions.explanation: The general format is: stream_object.open("filename", access mode); The second argument specifies the mode in which the file is opened.

questions.question: What is the default mode for ifstream functions?
questions.explanation: The default mode for ifstream functions is ios::in.

questions.question: What is the default mode for ofstream functions?
questions.explanation: The default mode for ofstream functions is ios::out.

questions.question: What does ios::app mode do?
options: Opens file in output mode with pointer at end, allows adding records
questions.explanation: ios::app opens the file in output mode. The file pointer is at the end of file and it can add a record.

questions.question: What does ios::ate mode do?
options: The file pointer is at the end of file and allows to add data or modify existing data anywhere
questions.explanation: ios::ate - The file pointer is at the end of the file and it allows to add data or to modify the existing data anywhere in the file.

questions.question: What does ios::trunc mode do?
options: Deletes the contents of the file if exist
questions.explanation: ios::trunc deletes the contents of the file if exist.

questions.question: What does ios::nocreate mode do?
options: If file is already present, it opens the file otherwise open fails
questions.explanation: ios::nocreate - If file is already present, it opens the file otherwise open fails.

questions.question: What does ios::noreplace mode do?
options: If file is not present, it opens the file otherwise open statement fails
questions.explanation: ios::noreplace - If file is not present, it opens the file otherwise open statement fails.

questions.question: What does ios::out mode do to existing file content?
options: Erases the content of the file
questions.explanation: ios::out opens the file in output mode. If it already has data, the output mode erases the content of the file.

questions.question: How can you combine multiple file mode parameters?
questions.explanation: The mode can combine two or more parameters using bitwise OR operator. Example: outfile.open("ABC.DAT", ios::in | ios::out | ios::binary);

questions.question: How many parameters do write() and read() functions have?
questions.explanation: The functions write() and read() have two parameters: address of the variable, size of the variable.

questions.question: The address of variable in read() and write() functions must be cast to:
questions.explanation: The address of the variable must be cast to the type char*. Example: infile.read((char*) & v, sizeof v);

questions.question: What is the general format for read() function?
questions.explanation: The general format is: infile.read((char*) & v, sizeof v); where v is the variable.

questions.question: How many pointers are associated with a file?
questions.explanation: File has two associated pointers called input pointer (or get pointer) and output pointer (or put pointer).

questions.question: What does seekg() function do?
options: Moves get pointer to a specified location
questions.explanation: seekg() moves get pointer to a specified location.

questions.question: What does seekp() function do?
options: Moves the put pointer to a specified location
questions.explanation: seekp() moves the put pointer to a specified location.

questions.question: What does ios::beg represent?
questions.explanation: ios::beg means beginning of the file.

questions.question: What does ios::cur represent?
questions.explanation: ios::cur means current position of the pointer.

questions.question: What does ios::end represent?
questions.explanation: ios::end means end of the file.

questions.question: What does infile.seekg(0, ios::beg); do?
options: Moves the pointer to the beginning of the file
questions.explanation: infile.seekg(0, ios::beg); moves the pointer to the beginning of the file. In this case, the refposition ios::beg is optional.

questions.question: What does infile.seekg(100, ios::cur); do?
options: Moves the pointer 100 bytes forward from the current position
questions.explanation: infile.seekg(100, ios::cur); moves the pointer 100 bytes forward from the current position.

questions.question: What does infile.seekg(-200, ios::end); do?
options: Moves pointer 200 bytes forward from end
Moves the pointer 200 bytes backward from the end of the file
questions.explanation: infile.seekg(-200, ios::end); moves the pointer 200 bytes backward from the end of the file.

questions.question: What does tellg() function do?
options: Gives the position of get pointer in terms of number of bytes
questions.explanation: The tellg() function gives the position of get pointer in terms of number of bytes.

questions.question: What does tellp() function do?
options: Gives the position of put pointer in terms of bytes
questions.explanation: Similarly, tellp() function gives the position of put pointer in terms of bytes.

questions.question: What is the general format for closing a file?
questions.explanation: The general format for closing a file is stream_object.close();

questions.question: When should a file be closed?
options: At the end if it is opened either through constructor or open() function
questions.explanation: The file should be closed at the end if it is opened either through constructor or open() function.

questions.question: In the example, what does file.clear() do?
options: To make the end of file mark false
questions.explanation: file.clear(); is used to make the end of file mark false, allowing further operations on the file.

questions.question: File operations covered in the lesson include:
options: Create, display, add new record, and modify existing record
questions.explanation: The lesson covers file operations including: Create a data file, Display a data file, Adding a new record, and Modify the existing record.
